attributes.title: Flow #2
attributes.description: What networks flow into and out of your life? A woman sits at her kitchen diner in Chula Vista, San Diego. She looks around, noting the first things upon which her eyes fall. Where did they come from? What stories do they tell? How do they connect her to strangers across the globe? Click on each point and read the story. (This map made with thanks to Map 4671)

attributes.title: Little Elivs's pencil
attributes.description: Chewed, with the ferrule missing, and a groove scraped down the seam by Elvis’s exploratory nail, the pencil lay forlorn on the kitchen floor next to the boy’s plastic play table. He’d been drawing with it this morning, mostly on the walls Sarah noted with a little chagrin. At least it would rub off. She paid as little notice to the instrument of this graffiti as she had when she purchased it. An unseen international presence in her home.

attributes.title: Staples Stationary
attributes.address: 1518 Sweetwater Road, National City, CA 91950, USA
attributes.description: Sarah wasn’t thinking much the day she bought the pencils. She drove into the parking lot near the stationary shop, and ducked in. She was actually looking for a present for her neice - a painting set maybe or a stenciling kit. In the end she settled on a scrap book, grabbing a couple of files for her utility bills and a box of standard pencils so she could mark up some sheet music. She paid, the cashier was sweet but a bit slow. Sarah had forgotten all about their conversation the moment she left the store.

attributes.title: Staples Distribution center
attributes.address: 1500 South Dupont Avenue, Ontario, CA 91761, USA
attributes.description: “Whoa, this place is HUGE,” exclaimed Bobby as his eyes rose, scanning the vast warehouse, to the ceiling 15 metres above him. Box upon identical box was stacked on pallets and shelves from floor to ceiling, conveyer belts and fork-lifts moving in a steady, unchoreographed dance. “40,000 square meters son,” said Ron, Bobby’s new supervisor. “It’s easy to know where to go to pick out orders,” he continued. “The light flashes on, showing you where you need to go. Soon it’ll be even easier, we’ll have an automated voice directing you around.” Bobby looked at the portly man next to him. “Great,” he said. “I won’t have to think at all.”

attributes.title: Pencil Factory
attributes.description: Green cupboards, blue overalls, yellow markings on the floor. Ana loved her job at the factory, making pencils. She’d come in every morning and see Matheus working the gate. They’d have a little chat and then she’d go in and get changed, becoming part of the colourful factory-scape. Ana worked on graphite pencils, gluing the wooden bodies to the lead. Every now and then she’s find one that wasn’t quite done right, and take it home for her son João. Today was one of those days. The lead was clearly broken, so she glued it, let it set and put it in her overall pocket as the rest of the pencils slid along the conveyer to the next station.
attributes.placename: Rua Coronel José Augusto de Oliveira Salles, 1876 - São Carlos - São Paulo, 13570-820, Brazil

attributes.title: Graphite Refinery
attributes.description: The smell of hot metal and dust permeates the air at the refinery. Rocks are pulverised, heated, dissolved. All in pursuit of carbon. Hui wanted to be a geologist; working in the refinery seemed like a good idea. He spent his evenings learning about the graphite they extracted - how it formed in crystals in schist from rocks heated and melted by the Earth’s movements. He sometimes got pains in his chest, but that could be the cigarettes he’d been smoking. He liked to watch the graphite granules cascade into buckets, catching the light, and imagine them turning into diamonds.
attributes.placename: 312 Provincial Road, Luodian, Qiannan, Guizhou, China

attributes.title: Graphite mine
attributes.address: Wenfeng St, Xintai, Tai'an, Shandong, China
attributes.description: Drills buzz, hammering into the rocky walls. Quiet. Muttering. The scuffled sound of feet on the move. Then BOOOOOOM! The stone, millennia in the making, crumbles and fractures. Ready, it’s ready now. Kuai calls the all clear to his colleagues, and down they go, a troupe of orange overalls into the depths. It had been a long shift. Just two more hours. Kuai shakes his beleaguered head to try to clear it as the last of the miners passed him. He looks to his left, down into the shaft. Looks up at the sky, towards the beautiful mountains he grew up in, memories of his family flooding his tired thoughts, just as he hears a shout from below.
attributes.placename: Wenfeng Street, Xintai, Tai'an, Shandong, China

attributes.title: Flax oil
attributes.description: “Flax growing is simply a means of making money,” wrote Vladimir Ilyich Lenin in his 1899 treatise on the development of capitalism in Russia, commenting on the expansion of commercial flax farming in his country over the previous 30 years. He juxtaposed this growth with increasing food imports, and pointed out that this change was damaging and degrading the farmers’ standard of living. Flax, he argued, was implicated in the commercialisation of rural societies in Russia. The crop can be grown on very poor soil, though, so how much does it compete? Nowadays 75,000 hectares of Russian land is devoted to growing flax, which produces not only oil but also fibres for linen cloth. How does this fit with Russia’s aim to become agriculturally 80 per cent self-sufficient by 2020?

attributes.title: Aluminium mine
attributes.description: Vlad’s car jolts as the left wheel hits another pothole. He pulls to a halt within walking distance of the site’s head office - a cabin dwarfed by the red slopes that wall in the open mine. His shoes and trousers become covered in the rust-coloured dust as he treads towards the half-ajar door. His second in command follows him, glancing up at the looming slopes when a deep boom in the tunnels below makes the ground shudder under their feet. He doesn’t bother to knock, wrenches the door open and walks in. “Mr Kobanyenko?” he pronounces, “we are here to audit you.”

attributes.title: Incense cedar
attributes.description: “It’s not as easy as it was,” grows a grizzled forester. Hunched over a cup of coffee, his padded lumberjack shirt barely holds in the biceps that have developed over 30 years in logging. “All these regulations. Global warming they say. All I know is, we have less work.”

attributes.title: Staples Stationary to Little Elivs's pencil
